misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the user can enter a point in the prompt format “(x1, y1):00” or “(x1, y1):0,0” and Scanner.nextDouble() will still correctly read both x and y values from that single entry.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Scanner.nextDouble() reads one numeric token at a time, splitting tokens by whitespace (by default). It will not automatically split "00" into two numbers, and it will not accept a comma inside a number token (e.g., "0,0"), which would cause an InputMismatchException. So unless the user types two whitespace-separated numbers (e.g., "0 0"), the program may block waiting for the second value or crash.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Potentially waits for more input (if user enters a single token like "00") or throws java.util.InputMismatchException (if user enters "0,0"), depending on how the user follows the prompt/sample I/O formatting.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the Scanner's nextDouble() method can parse individual digits from a single contiguous numeric string (like '50' or '05') into separate variables, or that it reads input digit-by-digit rather than token-by-token.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, the Scanner class uses whitespace (spaces, tabs, newlines) as a default delimiter to separate tokens. A contiguous sequence of digits such as '50' is interpreted as a single numeric token (the value 50.0). Calling nextDouble() twice does not split a two-digit number into two separate values; instead, it consumes the first entire number and then waits for a second distinct token in the input buffer.
